win_rules.rule_description: Tailor proposals to the priorities and concerns of sponsors, clients, or decision-makers. Understanding the audience is critical for presenting information at the right level of detail.
Clearly define scope, goals, deliverables, success criteria, and assumptions to align stakeholders around a shared understanding of what will be delivered.
Estimate costs, resources, and timelines to allow organizations to compare alternatives, evaluate feasibility, and reduce risk before committing resources.
In competitive contexts, use proposals to support bids, funding requests, and contract awards.
Internally, formalize ideas into actionable plans, serve as a reference for decisions and governance, and enable prioritization by showing how the project fits strategic objectives.
Use proposals at key decision points, before time, money, or project resources are committed, to provide structure for evaluation, approval, or alignment.
When responding to a Request for Proposal (RFP), adhere to the RFP guidelines of the project owner.
For unsolicited proposals, consider open bids or opportunities where proposals are accepted without a formal request.
When creating informal proposals, respond to direct requests from clients without an RFP.
For renewal proposals, highlight past positive results and future benefits to past customers.
For continuation proposals, communicate project progress to investors and stakeholders.
For supplemental proposals, communicate the need for additional resources during the project execution phase to investors.
Include a brief and to-the-point executive summary that outlines the project and its business justification, touching on information to follow.
Provide a concise project background (usually one page) explaining the problem to solve or opportunity to seize, with a short history of the business and its fit for the project.
State the project vision and specific success criteria, including the metrics used to measure success and how it aligns with company goals.
Detail potential risks and outline strategies for mitigation and for taking advantage of positive risks.
Define the project scope, including all necessary work and how it will be executed, and detail the various deliverables.
Describe the project approach and contract types (e.g., lump sum, cost plus, time and materials) and delivery methods.
Outline the expected benefits of successful project completion.
List all required resources, such as labor, materials, and equipment.
Detail all project costs, including resources, and set up a budget to show how these costs will be spent.
Lay out the project timeline from start to finish, including the duration of each phase and its tasks.
